name: Arunachal Pradesh
tagline: The Land of the Dawn-Lit Mountains

glance.landscapeType: Snow-capped peaks, deep valleys, alpine meadows

landMemory.narrative: Where India greets the first rays of the sun, Arunachal Pradesh rises in layers of mountains that have sheltered diverse communities for millennia. This is a land where Buddhism meets animism, where every mountain has a guardian spirit, and where the concept of nature and culture have never been separate.
keyTransitions: Ancient tribal kingdoms preserving unique identities
Buddhist monasteries establishing spiritual centers
Integration with India while maintaining cultural autonomy

communities.description: Home to 26 major tribes and over 100 sub-tribes, each valley in Arunachal hosts communities with distinct languages, customs, and governance systems that have evolved over centuries.

festivals.name: Losar
festivals.meaning: Tibetan New Year celebrated by Monpa people with prayers, dances, and community feasts

festivals.name: Mopin
festivals.meaning: Harvest festival of the Galo tribe invoking prosperity and driving away evil spirits

festivals.name: Solung
festivals.meaning: Agricultural festival of the Adi tribe celebrating the completion of sowing

culturalLife.foodCulture: Rice-based cuisine with bamboo shoots, wild herbs, and fermented preparations. Apong (rice beer) is central to social gatherings.

contributions.title: Forest Guardians
contributions.description: Community-managed forests using traditional conservation practices

contributions.title: Bamboo Artistry
contributions.description: Sustainable crafts using locally sourced materials passed down generations

contributions.title: Living Democracy
contributions.description: Village councils (Kebang) practicing consensus-based governance for centuries

experienceCategories.title: Sacred Landscapes
experienceCategories.description: Monasteries perched on mountains, sacred groves, and pilgrimage routes

experienceCategories.title: Tribal Heritage

experienceCategories.title: High Altitude Trails
experienceCategories.description: Treks through alpine meadows and snow-touched passes

name: Assam
tagline: The Gateway to the Seven Sisters

heroImage.caption: Tea gardens stretching to the horizon

glance.landscapeType: Brahmaputra plains, tea gardens, wildlife sanctuaries

landMemory.narrative: Assam is defined by the mighty Brahmaputra, one of the world's great rivers that brings both life and floods to this vast plain. For centuries, this was a crossroads—where traders, saints, and settlers from all directions met, creating a culture that embraces diversity while maintaining a distinct Assamese identity.
keyTransitions: Ancient Kamarupa kingdom spreading Tantric Buddhism
Ahom dynasty ruling for six centuries with unique governance
British tea plantations reshaping economy and demographics

communities.description: A mosaic of communities including Assamese, Bodo, Karbi, Mishing, Bengali settlers, and tea garden workers, all contributing to the state's cultural richness.

festivals.name: Bihu
festivals.meaning: The soul of Assam—three seasonal celebrations marking harvest, new year, and cattle with music and dance

festivals.name: Ambubachi Mela
festivals.meaning: Tantric festival at Kamakhya Temple celebrating the goddess and fertility

festivals.name: Me-Dam-Me-Phi
festivals.meaning: Ahom festival honoring ancestors and departed souls

culturalLife.foodCulture: Rice and fish are staples, flavored with mustard oil and herbs. Duck curry, pitha (rice cakes), and tamul-paan (betel nut) define Assamese hospitality.

contributions.title: Tea Heritage
contributions.description: Producer of over half of India's tea, with unique Assam varietals prized globally

contributions.title: One-Horned Rhino
contributions.description: Kaziranga and Manas—last strongholds of the Indian rhinoceros

contributions.title: Silk Traditions
contributions.description: Muga silk, golden and durable, woven nowhere else in the world

experienceCategories.title: Wildlife Encounters
experienceCategories.description: Rhinos, elephants, tigers in UNESCO World Heritage sites

experienceCategories.title: River Journeys
experienceCategories.description: Cruise the Brahmaputra, visit river islands, meet fishing communities

experienceCategories.title: Tea Heritage
experienceCategories.description: Stay in tea bungalows, walk the gardens, taste estate-made chai

heroImage.caption: Loktak Lake floating islands at dawn

glance.landscapeType: Central valley, surrounding hills, floating lakes

landMemory.narrative: Manipur is a valley ringed by hills, where the Meitei people developed one of the most sophisticated classical cultures in South Asia. Dance, martial arts, and polo (which originated here) share space with the traditions of hill tribes who have their own rich heritage. This is a land where resilience and beauty coexist.
keyTransitions: Ancient Meitei kingdom with unique script and calendar
Development of Manipuri classical dance and Thang-Ta martial arts
British influence and the sacrifices of Rani Gaidinliu

communities.description: The valley Meitei and hill communities like Tangkhul, Kabui, and Kuki have shaped a multi-layered culture where different traditions find expression.

festivals.name: Yaoshang
festivals.meaning: Holi celebrated with Thabal Chongba moonlit dances for five days

festivals.name: Lai Haraoba
festivals.meaning: Ancient festival invoking local deities through elaborate dance-dramas

festivals.name: Ningol Chakouba
festivals.meaning: Married daughters return to their maternal homes for a grand family feast

culturalLife.foodCulture: Fermented fish (ngari), bamboo shoots, and singju (spicy salad) define the cuisine. Eromba, a mashed vegetable dish, is comfort food.

contributions.title: Classical Dance
contributions.description: Manipuri dance, recognized among India's eight classical forms, known for its grace

contributions.title: Modern Polo Origin
contributions.description: Sagol Kangjei, the original form of polo, invented here centuries ago

contributions.title: Loktak Lake
contributions.description: World's only floating lake with unique phumdis (floating biomass) ecosystem

experienceCategories.title: Dance & Performance
experienceCategories.description: Witness classical dance, martial arts demonstrations, and ritual performances

experienceCategories.title: Floating World
experienceCategories.description: Explore Loktak Lake, stay on floating huts, meet the Keibul Lamjao deer

experienceCategories.title: Craft Villages
experienceCategories.description: Pottery at Thongjao, weaving at Wangkhei, metalwork at Andro

glance.landscapeType: Rolling hills, waterfalls, caves, living root bridges
glance.climate: Subtropical highland, among world's wettest regions

landMemory.narrative: Meghalaya is where the monsoon clouds come to rest, creating one of the wettest places on Earth. But this is not just about rain—it's about a matrilineal society where lineage passes through the mother, where communities grew bridges from living tree roots, and where the rhythm of the hills shaped a unique worldview.
keyTransitions: Autonomous Khasi and Garo kingdoms with distinct governance
British hill station development in Shillong
Modern recognition of matrilineal traditions and living root bridges

communities.description: Three main tribes—Khasi, Garo, and Jaintia—each with matrilineal traditions where children take their mother's surname and property passes through women.

festivals.name: Wangala
festivals.meaning: Garo 100-drum festival celebrating the harvest with music and dance

festivals.name: Shad Suk Mynsiem
festivals.meaning: Khasi thanksgiving dance festival where unmarried girls dance in ceremonial attire

festivals.name: Behdienkhlam
festivals.meaning: Jaintia festival to drive away evil and pray for good harvest

culturalLife.foodCulture: Pork dishes reign supreme—jadoh (pork rice), dohneiiong (pork with sesame), tungrymbai (fermented soybean). Rice beer flows freely at gatherings.

contributions.title: Living Architecture
contributions.description: Root bridges grown over generations—a UNESCO-recognized example of sustainable engineering

contributions.title: Matrilineal Society
contributions.description: One of the world's few matrilineal societies with unique family structures

contributions.title: Sacred Groves
contributions.description: Ancient community-protected forests preserving biodiversity through taboo and tradition

experienceCategories.title: Living Root Bridges
experienceCategories.description: Trek to bridges grown from tree roots over centuries

experienceCategories.title: Cave Exploration
experienceCategories.description: Longest caves in the subcontinent, many still unexplored

experienceCategories.title: Waterfall Trails
experienceCategories.description: Chase waterfalls during monsoon season's spectacular displays

name: Mizoram
tagline: The Land of the Blue Mountains

heroImage.caption: Rolling blue mountains and morning mist

glance.landscapeType: Endless rolling hills, bamboo forests, river valleys
glance.climate: Mild winters, pleasant summers, heavy monsoons

landMemory.narrative: Mizoram emerged from the Blue Mountains that roll endlessly into the horizon. Here, a society organized around the concept of 'Tlawmngaihna'—a code of selfless service and community responsibility—created one of India's most literate and tightly-knit states. The Mizo identity forged through common purpose remains strong.
keyTransitions: Migration legends from the Chin Hills
Christian missionary influence transforming society
Peaceful resolution of insurgency and statehood achievement

communities.description: A remarkably homogeneous society where the Mizo identity unites various clans, creating strong social cohesion and community bonds.

festivals.name: Chapchar Kut
festivals.meaning: Spring festival celebrating the completion of jhum (shifting cultivation) preparation

festivals.name: Mim Kut
festivals.meaning: Harvest festival honoring the departed with offerings of maize

festivals.name: Christmas
festivals.meaning: The most celebrated festival with entire communities gathering for music and feasts

culturalLife.foodCulture: Mizo cuisine features bai (leaf and vegetable stew), vawksa (pork preparations), and saum (fermented pork fat). Meals are simple but communal.

contributions.title: Tlawmngaihna Ethics
contributions.description: A social code of conduct emphasizing hospitality and selfless community service

contributions.title: Choral Traditions
contributions.description: Among India's finest choral music traditions, with churches doubling as music schools

contributions.title: Bamboo Conservation
contributions.description: Sustainable use of bamboo forests that cover much of the state

experienceCategories.title: Hill Village Life
experienceCategories.description: Stay in village homestays and experience daily Mizo life

experienceCategories.title: Blue Mountain Trails
experienceCategories.description: Trek through rolling hills with panoramic views at every turn

experienceCategories.title: Music & Worship
experienceCategories.description: Experience Sunday services with spectacular choral performances

heroImage.caption: Hornbill Festival performers in traditional warrior attire

glance.landscapeType: Steep mountains, terraced fields, misty valleys
glance.climate: Moderate summers, cold winters in higher elevations

landMemory.narrative: Nagaland is where sixteen major tribes, each fiercely independent, found unity in their shared love for their land. Once known for their warrior traditions and headhunting practices, the Naga people have preserved their distinct tribal identities while embracing modernity. The mountains here breed resilience.
keyTransitions: Independent tribal kingdoms with inter-village alliances
Christian conversion transforming social structures
Movement for Naga identity and subsequent peace accords

communities.description: Sixteen major tribes—Angami, Ao, Sumi, Lotha, Konyak, and more—each with unique dialects, customs, and traditional attire that they proudly display at festivals.

festivals.name: Hornbill Festival
festivals.meaning: Festival of Festivals celebrating all Naga tribes together with dance, music, and indigenous games

festivals.name: Moatsu
festivals.meaning: Ao tribe's post-sowing festival with feasting and folk songs

festivals.name: Sekrenyi
festivals.meaning: Angami purification festival with rituals spanning several days

culturalLife.foodCulture: Smoked and fermented meats, bamboo shoot preparations, axone (fermented soybean), and rice beer are central to Naga cuisine.

contributions.title: Festival Heritage
contributions.description: Each tribe's annual festival preserving ancient traditions in living form

contributions.title: Warrior Aesthetics
contributions.description: Shawls, spears, dao (machetes), and ornaments that are wearable identity

contributions.title: Community Governance
contributions.description: Traditional village councils (Morungs) maintaining social order

experienceCategories.title: Festival Experiences
experienceCategories.description: Time your visit to witness tribal festivals in villages

experienceCategories.title: Village Homestays
experienceCategories.description: Stay with Naga families, learn traditions, share meals

experienceCategories.description: Learn weaving, blacksmithing, and traditional arts from masters

glance.landscapeType: Himalayan peaks, alpine valleys, glacial lakes
glance.climate: Alpine to subtropical, varies with altitude

landMemory.narrative: In the shadow of Kanchenjunga, the world's third-highest peak, Sikkim evolved as a Buddhist kingdom where the Chogyal rulers fostered a culture of peace and reverence for nature. Today, as India's first fully organic state, Sikkim continues its tradition of living in harmony with its magnificent but fragile environment.
keyTransitions: Establishment of the Buddhist Namgyal dynasty
Monasteries becoming centers of learning and art
Merger with India while preserving cultural identity

communities.description: Three communities—Lepcha (original inhabitants), Bhutia (Tibetan origin), and Nepali settlers—have created a harmonious multicultural society united by Buddhist values.

festivals.name: Losar
festivals.meaning: Tibetan New Year with monastery prayers, masked dances, and community celebrations

festivals.name: Pang Lhabsol
festivals.meaning: Worship of Kanchenjunga, the guardian deity, with masked warrior dances

festivals.name: Saga Dawa
festivals.meaning: Buddha's birth, enlightenment, and death commemorated with pilgrimages and prayers

culturalLife.foodCulture: Momos (dumplings), thukpa (noodle soup), and gundruk (fermented greens) reflect Tibetan and Nepali influences. Tongba (millet beer) warms cold evenings.

contributions.title: Organic Pioneer
contributions.description: India's first 100% organic state, banning chemical farming entirely

contributions.title: Buddhist Heritage
contributions.description: Ancient monasteries preserving Vajrayana Buddhism and Tibetan arts

contributions.title: Sustainable Tourism
contributions.description: Model for managing tourism in fragile mountain ecosystems

experienceCategories.title: Monastery Circuit
experienceCategories.description: Visit ancient Buddhist monasteries with panoramic Himalayan views

experienceCategories.title: High Altitude Lakes
experienceCategories.description: Journey to sacred lakes like Gurudongmar and Tsomgo

experienceCategories.title: Kanchenjunga Views
experienceCategories.description: Multiple vantage points to witness the guardian peak at sunrise

glance.landscapeType: Low hills, plains, bamboo forests, river valleys
glance.climate: Tropical monsoon with warm temperatures year-round

landMemory.narrative: Tripura was an independent kingdom for over two thousand years, ruled by the Manikya dynasty who traced their lineage to lunar gods. Despite being surrounded by Bangladesh on three sides, Tripura forged a unique identity blending indigenous Tiprasa culture with Bengali influences, creating a land where temple traditions meet tribal heritage.
keyTransitions: Manikya dynasty establishing a sophisticated court culture
Integration with India while maintaining princely traditions
Balancing tribal and settler community relations

communities.description: Indigenous Tiprasa (nineteen tribes including Tripuri, Reang, Jamatia) alongside Bengali settlers have created a bilingual, bicultural society.

festivals.name: Kharchi Puja
festivals.meaning: Worship of the fourteen gods of the Tripuri pantheon at the Chaturdash Devata temple

festivals.name: Garia Puja
festivals.meaning: Tribal spring festival invoking Garia deity for prosperity and good harvest

festivals.name: Durga Puja
festivals.meaning: Grand Bengali celebrations with elaborate pandals and community gatherings

culturalLife.foodCulture: Bengali and tribal cuisines coexist—fish preparations with mustard, bamboo shoot curries (gudok), and various pitha (rice cakes).

contributions.title: Fourteen Gods Tradition
contributions.description: Unique syncretic worship blending tribal and Hindu deities

contributions.title: Bamboo Heritage
contributions.description: Intricate bamboo work from houses to household items

contributions.title: Royal Legacy
contributions.description: One of India's oldest continuous dynasties until modern integration

experienceCategories.description: Ancient temples and royal palaces telling stories of the Manikya kings
